column34: Please let us know where you heard about us?

column10: There is a wide-bodied commercial pickup truck (the kind that hauls mulch) that parks on-street here all the time, even though it doesn’t fit and blocks half of the southbound bike lane.

To go around a truck blocking the southbound bike lane (too wide for parking spot), I pulled into the driving lane (w/ 6yo son on the back). The driver 2 cars back laid on the horn then angrily drove past within inches after I pulled back over.; Driving lane, too; Aggressive drivinf
I was just approaching the inside parking lot when a car leaving the community ran me down. Several injuries to me. Nothing to driver of automobile.

Vehicles turning from East Glebe from either direction to go South on Route 1. Pedestrians are an afterthought and we had to jump out of the way multiple times to avoid vehicles turning to us. The vehicles just don't expect pedestrians to be on the road.
Drivers cannot see people in the bike lane due to parked cars which are too close to the intersection. In fact, some of the signs are not in compliance with city staff.
Driver making right hand turn failed to yield to 4 pedestrians in the crosswalk, including an infant
Driver turned right immediately in front of cyclist in bike lane when cyclist arrived at stop sign first.

People walking, biking and driving have a hard time seeing each other due to poor visibility. Pulling back parking here would allow everyone to see each other. I have had several near misses while biking along this route.
Car was parked in bike lane, despite the availability of parallel parking spaces nearby
column34: Met someone at Bike to Work Day

column10: driver on Reed was 2nd in line after driver at stop sign waited for crossing guard okay. 2nd in line driver pulled into oncoming lane and attempted to enter intersection while students were in crosswalk. driver then sped into left turn and up commonwealth; crossing guard on duty

We were 6 pedestrians, 5 adults and one 6 year old and a taxi turning left from commonwealth to Ashby turned right into us as we crossed and had to slam its breaks to avoid hitting us. Nearest miss I’ve ever had as a pedestrian

Driver making right turn at green light did not check the bike lane before turning and struck a cyclist.  No injures and minor damage to bike.  Police not contacted.  Location is 1 block away from elementary school and children are frequently present.  Drivers frequently make right turns at this light without checking bike lane or use bike lane as a turning lane.

Reckless motor vehicle operator tuning left from Reed to southbound Commonwealth ignored stop sign at >10 mph.  This person engaging in dangerous behavior could have hit a pedestrian, cyclist or another motor vehicle.
column21: Recommend redesigning intersection to make it less comfortable for motor vehicle operators to ignore signage less than 1 block away from elementary school.  Suggestions include narrowing the street and installing raised crosswalks.  Bike lanes protected with bollards or concrete dividers would have a similar effect.
